greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = minimal integer m such that there exists an m X m integer matrix of order n.
comment: Also lowest dimension in which rotational symmetry of order n is possible for an infinite regular set of points (previously A028496). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Feb 02 2020
reference: J. E. Goodman and J. O'Rourke, editors, Handbook of Discrete and Computational Geometry, CRC Press, 1997, p. 935 (note has erroneous value of a(11)).
Marjorie Senechal, Quasicrystals and Geometry, Cambridge University Press, 1985, p. 51.
link: Howard Hiller, The Crystallographic Restriction in Higher Dimensions, Acta Cryst. (1985), A41, 541-544.
formula: a(1)=0, a(2)=1. If n mod 4 eq 2 then a(n)=a(n/2).
Otherwise a(n) = sum (pi-1)*pi^(ei-1) where n = p1^e1*p2^e2*...pk^ek is prime factorization of n.
program: if n le 2 then return n-1; end if;
if n mod 4 eq 2 then n := n div 2; end if;
xref: See A080737 for another version. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 05 2008
results.author: W. R. Unger (billu(AT)maths.usyd.edu.au), Dec 04 2008
